item.title: Spain's conservatives miss out on all-out victory as left celebrates
item.description: Popular Party leader Alberto Núñez Feijóo narrowly wins but is held back by left-wing parties.

item.title: Rhodes: Holidaymakers describe wildfires ordeal
item.description: Tourists describe their emergency evacuation and people being covered in ash on the Greek island.

item.title: Corfu latest Greek island to evacuate over wildfires
item.description: The popular tourist island has started evacuations after 19,000 had to leave Rhodes.

item.title: Taliban beauty salon ban: Three Afghan women mourn the end of a valued service
item.description: Women tell the BBC about what they will miss from salons before they close on orders from the Taliban.

item.title: Manipur: The women facing the fire of the conflict
item.description: A viral video of an attack on two women in Manipur is encouraging other survivors to speak out.

item.title: Fifa Women's World Cup day five preview: Italy v Argentina, Germany v Morocco, Brazil v Panama
item.description: What to expect from day five of the Fifa Women's World Cup, with Italy facing Argentina, Germany playing Morocco and Brazil meeting Panama.

item.title: Ukraine war: Russia hits Odesa after killing grain deal
item.description: Russia is hammering Ukraine's port city of Odesa after quitting the grain deal. What happens now?

item.title: Labour leadership sees off demand for new spending commitments
item.description: The party says it has agreed an ambitious programme without the need for new spending commitments.

item.title: Israel judicial reform: Netanyahu in hospital ahead of key vote
item.description: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu had surgery to fit a pacemaker, days before a crucial vote on legal reforms.

item.title: Cambodia election: 'This was more of a coronation than an election'
item.description: Prime Minister Hun Sen's son is expected to take over within weeks of the vote.

item.title: Barbie movie wins box office battle in US
item.description: Barbie has the year's most successful opening weekend for a film in the US and Canada, making $155m.

item.title: Novak Djokovic withdraws from Toronto Masters event with fatigue
item.description: Novak Djokovic withdraws from next month's Canadian Open in Toronto because of fatigue.

item.title: Latitude closes with George Ezra on 'Singalong Sunday'
item.description: George Ezra, James, The Bootleg Beatles, Mimi Webb and Siouxsie appear on the final day.

item.title: The Papers: 'Hell on Earth' and Tories' green policy 'retreat'
item.description: Monday's papers chronicle the plight of holidaymakers fleeing fires in Rhodes, and the Tory debate on green policies.

item.title: Locals step in to help tourists after Rhodes fires
item.description: Families on the island have offered up their spare bedrooms and sofas to stranded holidaymakers.

item.title: Snapchat: Does app give drug gangs access to teenagers?
item.description: An undercover BBC investigation finds drug gangs are using social media to recruit children.

item.title: Why is technology not making us more productive?
item.description: We are in the midst of a technological revolution, but productivity has not improved.

item.title: 'How are we supposed to feel?' - Ashes hopes washed away
item.description: The rain-ruined draw in the fourth Ashes Test was an anti-climax, but England must rouse themselves for the finale at The Oval, says chief cricket writer Stephan Shemilt.

item.title: Harry Styles: How pop star was taught to ride a horse for video
item.description: The singer hit his stride with advice from a stunt company based in Hertfordshire.

item.title: Elon Musk: Time to say goodbye to Twitter logo
item.description: The Twitter owner says he wants to replace the logo with an "X".

item.title: Town celebrates Robert Burns' first book of poems
item.description: An Ayrshire town is celebrating the first book of poems from Scotland's national bard.

item.title: The 1975 cancels Indonesia and Taiwan shows after Malaysia LGBT row
item.description: The band has cancelled upcoming concerts in Indonesia - where homosexuality is shunned - and Taiwan.

item.title: Vingegaard retains Tour de France title
item.description: Denmark's Jonas Vingegaard seals his second successive Tour de France triumph as Jordi Meeus sprints to a surprise win on the final stage.

item.title: 'Brutal' race conditions force 86 yachts to retire
item.description: Competitors in the 50th Rolex Fastnet Race set off from Cowes on the Isle of Wight on Saturday.

item.title: Lady Florence Dixie: The aristocrat who fought for women's football
item.description: Lady Florence Dixie from southern Scotland was the first president of the British Ladies Football Club.

item.title: The Open: Brian Harman wins Claret Jug at Royal Liverpool by six shots
item.description: Brian Harman overcomes an early wobble to stroll serenely to his first major title with a six-shot victory at the 151st Open Championship in Hoylake.

item.title: Diamond League London: Zharnel Hughes breaks men's 200m British record
item.description: Zharnel Hughes breaks the British record for the men's 200m with a time of 19.73s at the London Diamond League.

item.title: Harry Kane: Top European clubs holding out for Tottenham striker
item.description: Some of Europe's leading clubs believe there is a possibility Tottenham will sell striker Harry Kane this summer.

item.title: Zharnel Hughes: Sprinter again predicts British record run at London Diamond League
item.description: Zharnel Hughes reveals he again predicted his British record run after clocking 19.73 seconds in the 200m at the London Diamond League.

item.title: The Open 2023: Watch Brian Harman's winning final round at Hoylake
item.description: Watch Brian Harman's final round at Royal Liverpool as he wins his first major title with a six-shot victory at the 151st Open Championship.

item.title: The Ashes 2023: Australia retain the urn after rain ensures fourth Test ends in draw
item.description: England's hopes of an Ashes comeback are heartbreakingly ended by rain that leaves the fourth Test as a draw and ensures Australia retain the urn.

item.title: Mortgages: What happens if I am struggling to pay?
item.description: Many homeowners are worried about higher mortgage costs, but lenders must help those struggling.

item.title: Train strikes: Walkouts hit start of UK summer holidays
item.description: Members of the RMT union at 14 rail companies will walk out on Saturday as many school holidays begin.

item.title: Rent increases: What you can do about a rise from your landlord
item.description: The BBC's Lora Jones tells you four things you can do, if your landlord asks for more money.

item.title: What is GDP and how is it measured?
item.description: A basic guide to how the economy is measured and what that calculation is used for.

item.title: Cost of living: How can I save money on my food shop?
item.description: The cost-of-living crisis continues to bite. Here are some things that can reduce the impact.

item.title: Why inflation is falling but prices are still rising
item.description: We report this percentage every month but here are three things you may not know.

item.title: Cheaper train tickets: Five ways to save money
item.description: As rail fares increase, we find the ways passengers can keep journeys as cheap as possible.

item.title: Mortgage rates: Five ways to save money
item.description: With interest rates rapidly rising, what do experts say about coping with costs?

item.title: Renting: What are your rights as a tenant?
item.description: With one in five people now renting in the UK, it's important to understand your rights as a tenant.

item.title: What are my rights if my flight is cancelled?
item.description: Strikes and poor weather may cause disruption at airports, but passengers do have rights.
